pros: Oracle's SaaS solutions, strategy, and roadmap is the very best in the industry. Due to their ability to offer a full suite of solutions for every major functional area of the business, their only real competitors are Netsuite (built for the very low end of the market) and SAP (who is still re-writing their legacy, core ERP application to be a true SaaS solution. Until such time that they complete that massive undertaking, SAP remains an on-premise app that's simply hosted in someone's data center. Despite other companies who might offer higher base salaries, Oracle continues to deliver the highest W2s to it's top-performing sales professionals. If you're really good at sales (or aspire to be), you want to work here.
cons: Oracle is a very large company, which means that sometimes things aren't always as easy as everyone would like them to be. While that's been the case for many years, top leadership has worked hard to improve our processes and systems. And since we use our own systems here, the improvements in both of those things over the last few years has been incredible. Oracle is still not the place to be for someone who doesn't want to work hard and/or who has an aversion to having their performance closely monitored. In short, expect to be rewarded for high performance and expect to not enjoy it if you're the kind of employee who likes to just get by.

review_title: They can only value you to an extent
pros: Working for Oracle has its perks. You can switch teams easily and really get a sense for what you want to do with your life. Work life balance is great. Everyone is pretty nice and collaborative.
cons:
- Get as high of an offer right off the bat as its close to impossible to get meaningful raises and promotions (take this from someone who is performing top 5% in productivity, etc). Expect to be paid 30-40% less than you can in the market 

- Expect to be promoted only when someone leaves the company or there is a re org. Expect to get passed up on promotions to people with tenure rather than merit. 

- Expect to work with a lot of complacent people. If you work hard it makes it easy to get noticed but with the red tape at Oracle its hard for them to move you up the ladder, get paid more etc anyway

- You wont have resources like being able to demo your solution,etv

- They make changes on pricing, packaging and the product for their own benefit not because it will help the customer. Thats a scary place to be.

review_title: No soul, but a lot of corporate bureaucracy
pros: - Lot of good learning sources are available for employees
cons:
- All projects I worked on used old technologies. If you are looking to learn how to use some modern tech stacks, forget about this.
- Salaries (at the moment of writing this review) are below average. When people started to talk about that and pointed out that Oracle's competitors has 30-40% higher payments, Oracle did nothing. Someone got a bit of RSUs as bonus
- No salary adjustment to inflation
- In order to get promotion you should push yourself very hard. Managers no willing to give you promotion except you showed some very exclusive achievements.
- Corporate bureaucracy is everywhere.
- You want new mouse, keyboard or LED display? Well forget about that. I almost begged my managers for new mouse. 
- Budget for visiting conferences and workshop is so low that it's barely will be enough some paid online event.
- Maybe not a con for everybody, but teams I worked in had no any interactions with other teams around the world.

pros: COVID pay, good insurance at a low rate, allowing us to keep our workflows intact after acquisition

still many smart people working together to get things done

Sales org churn is a given and it is hurting the bottom line

review_title: Excellent design organization in a ruthless business
pros: In recent years Oracle's design organization has thrived. Most design teams on individual products left local product management departments and joined a company-wide Design organization. The Redwood design system is not complete, but it is high quality. Designers get a lot of support and can do great work.
cons: There is a lot of excellent design work that the product teams never build. Selling your work is a much more significant part of the job than I've seen elsewhere. Funding for most designers still comes from the product teams. If Oracle cuts down the product team, the designer will lose their position. Oracle is quite ruthless, so you must watch for the signs of your project dying and try to move before the axe falls. However, the Design Org tries to move designers to other open positions before laying them off.

review_title: Oracle is huge but Netsuite is not.
job_title: Human Resources Business Partner HRBP in Denver, CO
pros: Lots of specialty experts. Such as compensation, benefits, recruiting, Legal, payroll within the broader Oracle ecosystem. The Netsuite global business unit is one of the fastest growing and most profitable within the broader oracle. A very entrepreneurial type of culture with people at its forefront. Super leaders from top down. Collaborative work environment.
cons: HR rolls up to the broader oracle so while you are a HR business partner to Netsuite, HR rules and regulations etc. are aligned with Oracle policies and procedures. So a bit less flexible than when Netsuite was a public company before Oracle acquired them. Because of the many specialty departments as mentioned above, HR business partners are generally working on assisting with compensation offers as well as compensation changes within the next week business unit and employee relations which Kloots ploy conflicts, manager employee conflicts, employee complaints related to more complex issues such as discrimination or harassment type complaints. The US HR group in the broader oracle ecosystem are working on some innovative ways to allow the business partners to work on more complex and strategic projects and leaving them more routine type duties to lower level HR consultants, still full-time regular employees, who would like to build their skill set to be an HR business partner in the future. This will allow the HR business partner to spend more time strategizing with business leaders then doing more routine or Munding tasks. Especially if you are an experienced HR business partner.

review_title: Tactical Leader / Strategic Laggard: #1 in Database 4th or 5th in Cloud
job_title: Master Principal Solution Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: (1) Oracle is full of strong people: Sales / Engineering / Product Management (2) If "Data is the New Oil" Oracle Database is still the best in the business for large scale - mission critical workloads (3) The Exadata Family of On-Premise/Cloud Offerings (Hybrid Cloud) provides a turbocharge for all of your Big Data Needs (4) Good Benefits - Healthcare is a well funded! (5) Fair pay for the role you join today!
cons: (1) Oracle struggles to compete for mindshare with AWS/Azure/Google Cloud.... So it is a strong 4th or 5th - IBM probably the next biggest competitor. (2) Secret-Secret Who's got the Secret??: Oracle operates on a need to know basis - Oracle is the 1st company I have worked for that does not trust it's employees with information. These leads to poor cross pillar internal collaboration and "Customer Frustration". (3) Legacy Software Licenses is their most valuable asset! - NOT PEOPLE! Enough said, on software licenses and the barriers put up to maintain those assets. PEOPLE are just fungible resources that can be easily pulled in or out! Don't expect any loyalty from your efforts at Oracle - Its all transactional! - You sell your get paid - You provide great customer service yesterday doesn't mean you'll be rewarded tomorrow. (4) Oracle places the most effort on Tactical Execution and Licenses (that doesn't imply they do it well); Strategy (Hmmm... From my vantage point Oracle's biggest weaknesses are 'Strategic Thinking" and "Innovation"). As a serial acquirer they have made huge investments in PeopleSoft, Siebel, JD Edwards, BEA Systems, Hyperion, NetSuite, Sun Micro Systems and the latest big buy, CERNER the strong #2 in Healthcare -- Why not Epic the Leader? Oracle has bought many businesses over the years - They might integrate these cash cows into the business - but they will languish and in almost all cases lack the innovative capabilities that they acquired. Net-Net: if you want to work for a strong large firm that is a player in the Top-10 Technology Providers - Oracle will provide a good place to work. If you are looking for an innovative tech company that values people..... You might want to look somewhere else. Advice: If you are under <40: Look somewhere else for employment. If you are over >40: Oracle is a good weigh station to learn some new skills - But don't stop looking for stronger opportunities and move on quickly.

You will find arrogant/aggressive/loud people in leadership roles.

If you ask questions you will be told that you ask "support-like questions" and are too dumb to understand anything. And if you don't you cannot do your job and if you try again your manager will scream at you and eat you for breakfast and lunch. 
Abusive managers justify their anger/frustration at you by saying that you don't think/work like them. I lost all hope when this abusive guy was promoted and everyone in my team and other teams knows what kind of environment he has created and how toxic is he. Tried complaining to HR also but nothing happened, they will ask you to level up your game.
They could be right, this could have been working for them or others in the team but not for me. I have been trying to do my job but I am not allowed to ask questions and am shouted at if I try. Be prepared if you are planning to join.

review_title: If you want to experience the most toxic culture in a workplace, ODP Sydney is the role for you!
pros: Technology is great. Some people on the floor are very genuine, and intelligent. SEs, Sales Support. If you're an Solutiom Consultant you will be okay here, but I do not recommend joining Sales team.
cons:
I read another post here about corrupt Sales management. I'm not sure who they're referring to specifically but I do know that under the table money deals do happen and is more rife.

Most of us here are from "the subcontinent" and I can see that the bias, bullying, and under the table dealings are rife. I've seen people who are locals or other nationalities bullied out of this workplace repeatedly.

None of the current Sales Managers were successful Sales stars in their previous life, and promotion is done through sucking up.

Reps are blamed for everything, salary is poor at best, customers are not happy as ODP has audited and burned all customers in the past.

Even if you hit 100% of quota you will not make your promised commission here because the Commission structure is biased, and if you bring on a good account the FLMs will switch territories in someone else's favour that they like.

Hoping someone in the Oracle corp reads this and does the needful on our department, as something desperately needs to change.

review_title: Good company, chaotic management excellent opportunities in design
pros: If you're employed in the states your pay will be high not so much in the rest of the world but you will get good benefits, flexible working depending on your manager, team and responsibilities. f you are a designer Oracle is behind many other companies in term of the design of its current products which means there is a lot of scope to improve them and currently a huge push to use and improve their new design system for all existing and future applications. For someone who is ambitious and looking for experience in large MNO Oracle is good. You can get good benefits if you perform well and share packages are available. Training opportunities are pretty good overall.
cons: If you move laterally and get a pay rise in the move you won't get a pay rise for two years. Its hard to get above average pay rises and progress up the ranks can be slow within the team however lateral moves are possible and you can leave and return to the company up to two times which is nice. Management can be a bit too political but again like any company that depends on the team and the individuals you happen to be working with or for.

pros: Oracle has been a great place to start my career. They have invested in me and given me plenty of opportunities to learn new skills. I studied statistics in college, but was able to transition into a software engineering role with no experience because it was interesting to me and something that I wanted to learn. I'm able to achieve a good work/life balance (which is important to me) and am surrounded by a lot of very smart people.
cons: Compensation has been a source of frustration for many of us. Oracle will only adjust your salary once a year (at most), even if you transition to another role with more responsibility during that time (e.g. individual contributor to manager). Last year was my first compensation adjustment after THREE YEARS with the company. Expect a lot of re-orgs and RIFs, which is obviously bad for company morale.

review_title: Good place to start your career... but that's it
pros:
- Good onboarding training program.
- Good place to start your career so you can go somewhere you will be valued.
- Great place to network and meet smart, talented people.
cons:
- Compensation for Solution Engineers is seriously lacking compared to the industry standard. By a significant amount.
- Raises are few and far between. I was lucky to randomly get promoted and a pay raise (still not at the amount other companies pay SEs of similar experience). It is well known that the best way to get a significant pay increase at Oracle is to leave and be rehired.
- The culture is extremely toxic and overly competitive. Women at Oracle are frequently ignored and talked over - very much a "boy's club." The company also has very little diversity. Employment is a revolving door for a reason here.
- The vacation policies are lackluster in 2022, where other companies are recognizing the importance of work-life balance. 4 days of PTO are mandatory for every employee each year for winter break. This leaves a measly 8-9 of accrued time to use at your discretion. 
- Employees are forced to jump through hoops to log overtime hours and this is actively discouraged, even if you are working more than you should be.
- Management does not care about you, your compensation, happiness, success or career goals. All they care about is looking good in the eyes of their manager.
- Outdated business processes and mediocre product offerings.

pros: Benefits are great--health and other benefits are really excellent
cons: The CEO's behavior regarding Trump is outrageous. Google him. Employees must take compliance and ethics courses and the CEO displays despicable behavior. There is an incredible lack of respect for employees. Raises are nonexistent. People have written that here and it is not from poor performers; it is a fact. CEO purchased an $80,000,000 house in Florida that he is tearing down--it could have been a bonus. Some employees actually have applied for food stamps. If you apply and are offered a position, consider what your salary should be in 5 years and then ask for that. You won't get a raise so you'll need enough to cover lack of salary. This is true whether the business is doing great or not. Of course, execs will get their raises. It's a good place to work to get started, learn, and then leave when it makes sense to do so.

review_title: Good and Stable company for freshers
pros:
Hi, Currently I am working in OFSS as Associate Consultant.Basically,joined OFSS as a fresher on 31st August 2021.
With my experience till now I must say that this is a good company for fresher whose looking for good technical career growth.

Work Culture: 
Here all the employees are very friendly, I never expected that I have got good peers in my first company.
All employees are really helpful. My seniors and team leader are always help me when I was stuck in my work.
Good Work Life balance and they do have option of flexible to work from home.

Tech Learning:
Here the Training sessions are really good , the training instructors are really helpful and 
I learned lot of technologies specially on the java training where we do have a lot of study materials.
Currently I am working on new technologies and have a good scope to improve my technical skills.


Compensation:
As I am Freshers I think OFSS gives the good freshers salary w.r.t the other companies.
I am happy with my salary.

Other benefits:
In OFSS they provide many other benefits also, specially during covid cases.

Regular Hikes:
I have heard from other peers that they have part of appraisal cycle and they have been rewarded nicely, In same manner
I am looking forward to my appraisal very soon.

I must say that OFSS is really a good company to start your career and also for learning the new technologies.
You never regret to join in OFSS. And main thing all the employees are very Polite in nature. They always ready for helping you.

review_title: Would not recommend. Maybe for a short stay, but definitely not a forever home.
pros: Great pay, reasonable time off, interesting work.
cons: Really, really poor leadership. Incredibly aggressive deadlines that aren't reasonable. Lack of clarity when it comes to technical debt. Un-payable technical debt accrues to the point where you actually do need tons of engineers to work on the projects just to make minute changes. That's a very backwards and outdated engineering approach. Doesn't come close to an ideal experience for both engineers and customers. Even though unlimited PTO exists, lots of people are working more than 8 hrs a day, and find it difficult to actually allow themselves to take days off. The public voices speak, "Support, help, and don't work overtime", but the deadlines and goals that are set speak, "work overtime, we aren't supporting you, we want to squeeze everything out of you." Repeatedly I requested adjusted communications to customers and leaders with regards to aggression on completing work. While I was able to get less pressure for myself, that really couldn't be exercised because the same treatment wasn't being applied to the rest of the team. There wasn't consistency in how leader/follower relationships were managed, and if someone allowed them to be pushed because they trusted their leaders, the leaders took full advantage of that. If you were vulnerable to working long hours without additional reward, you were taken advantage of and not rewarded properly.

review_title: Not the best place to work if you want advancement.
pros: You can work from home. Yep that is about all. Oh and the paychecks clear the bank.
cons:
The work life balance is terrible. They always want more of your time. You're constantly filling out administrative paperwork for billing purposes and then questioned on why your spending time doing administrative tasks. 

You will not be offered raises even a simple cost of living increase. This isn't part of the Oracle model. You only get a pay increase for advancing to other areas in the company. If you want to find a place and be happy good luck. Eventually they will just lay you off anyway. They do not value the long term employees.

In the devaluing of the employees it also shows in the customer service provided. That is why the hospitality global unit is losing customers at an alarming rate. This pillar of the company is grossly undervalued and treated as if it isn't important. Therefore the customers are in turn being treated in the same fashion.

review_title: Work that Inspires, Culture that Supports
pros: Having the best Cloud technology in the industry, our work has a tangible impact on thousands of lives. In Change Navigation, we especially focus on the human side of technology transformation. By far the best part of working at Oracle is our culture. Everyone supports your personal career journey, challenges you to become the best version of yourself, and cares deeply for your mental and personal health. I could not imagine a better situation to start and grow my career!
cons: In Consulting, you're never 100% sure what your work and responsibilities are going to look like day-to-day. If you are someone who likes to know exactly what they are responsible for, then the flexibility and freedom in Consulting may not be for you. Also, Oracle does a fantastic job supporting an entrepreneurial mindset, but being a massive company, there is only so much innovation that can occur at one time. If you're looking to make immediate, broad changes or innovations, it may be best to look for a smaller company.

review_title: Good company in the middle of change
pros:
- Work-life balance (depends on your manager, but overall pretty good)
- Compensation (in line with industry's peers)
- Bonus (especially if you are on a 60-40, 70-30, 80-20 scheme)
- Stability (usually if the teams are disbanded, you can find internally a new job)
- Great place if you want to enjoy your life, but have a slow-paced development
- Autonomy (you are allowed to lead projects, programs, and initiatives without leaders interference)
cons:
- Targets (sometimes not realistic)
- Vision (lack of vision from top leadership is something you need to get used to it)
- Politics (similar to other companies, skills are important, but politics is much more important)
- Career progression (not all the time the promotion based on the results/ skills. I've seen promotions without results and results without promotion)
- Salary increases only when you are promoted to another band/ level
- Change (leaders do not have the patience to stick with a model and allow it to get mature, but are changing the structure/ frameworks, processes, roles, etc.)
- Tools & systems

pros: Good Money for the amount of work
cons: Very political internally & alot of changes

pros: It's nice to work with other people who are early in career.
cons: In the BDR program, they treat you horribly and have the attitude that if you don't like it you can leave. They include clauses in your commission plan that allow them to decide whether or not they feel like paying you full commission, even though BDR's are already the lowest paid employees. The training is not relevant to the day-to-day function of the role and doesn't prepare you for the job or roles that follow. The employee retention rate is dropping rapidly because all sales reps at NetSuite are severely underpaid compared to competitors offering double pay for the same work. Because there's so much employee turnover, it's not uncommon to get assigned a new manager every 2 quarters which makes it challenging to continue training and to do well. Management does not respect employees and will openly treat people poorly if they are not in the top 10%. If management wants something done, they incentivize with threats instead of benefits or encouragement. If you have the option, avoid this role at all costs. There are better opportunities elsewhere that will get you farther in your career.

Higher management always comes with changes in procedures and more things to do, mostly procedural things not directly related with work, so you have less and less time to actually do your work.
Latest meetings had an intermediary between VP and rest of us, who "translated" our questions so they sound "nicer" and sometimes lost their meaning, thus reminded me on communist times when we all needed to report only increases in production and that all is very good.
You are asked to think out of the box, but in the meantime you are compelled to follow so many rules, so in fact there is no freedom for out of the box thinking.

Promotion chance depends heavily upon department.
